title: What are the similarities and differences of the four major schools of thought (idealism, realism, pragmatism and critical realism) in philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question presumes that “Idealism, Realism, Pragmatism and Critical Realism” comprise the “four major schools” of Philosophy. Actually, there are many other schools with just as much right to be counted among any list of the “four major schools.” Existentialism and the Dialectic are only two. Anyway, I would answer this question in this form: “compare and contrast Idealism, Realism, Pragmatism and Critical Realism.” To undertake this potentially mammoth task in a brief space, I will make my text as terse as I can. Idealism: Reality is ultimately Ideas, so that Ideas and Ideals not only predominate, but also “rule” over Material objects. Plato was the first Westerner to write out this “dualist” approach to Reality. Today we call it, “Mind over Matter,” or “Spirit over Nature,” or “Will Power over the Appetites” and so on.Realism: Reality is ultimately Material objects, which exist independently of Ideas and the Mind. Matter predominates and even “rules” over Ideas. Aristotle is credited as the first Westerner to imply this “dualist” approach to Reality. Today we call this “being realistic,” and “accepting things as they are.” (Traditionally speaking, Idealism and Realism are opposites.)Pragmatism: Reality is ultimately comprised of those Material objects that the Mind chooses to Experience. Some objects are “important” and most objects are “unimportant.” Reality is always lived in this ranking of objects, and the ranking is entirely Ideal, although the objects are entirely Material. (Traditionally, this view is a synthesis of Idealism and Realism.)Critical Realism: Reality is ultimately comprised of those Material objects that the Mind can control scientifically. Anything that the Mind cannot control turns out to be irrelevant, no matter what our opinion of it might be. This view presumes some degree of Science, no matter how slight. (Traditionally, this view is an elaboration of Pragmatism.)There, in very brief terms, is a comparison and a contrast of those four generic schools of Philosophy.

I’m not sure what you mean, but I’ll take a shot. Within one particular area of philosophy, the philosophy of perception (itself only a part of epistemology), there might fairly be said to be the four major schools of thought you name. The specific question addressed by each school is: what is the relationship between what is perceived on the one hand, and the image of the perceived thing WITHIN a perceiving mind on the other? That question has, one might say, four answers. Idealism: there is no duality, The apple I perceive and the idea I have of it when I perceive it are the same fact, because “to be is to be perceived.”Realism: there is a duality. When I perceive an apple my senses are conveying to my mind various data about the apple and my mind is putting it together. The synthesis of those data is imperfect, prone to error, but for people with normal healthy senses and nervous system it is usually pretty accurate.Pragmatism: there are different contexts. If I am a painter, the ‘reality’ of the apple is not my concern. It is part of the scenery that is inspiring my brush strokes and that is sufficient. If I am starving and in desperate need of food, I can assure myself of the reality of the apple by grasping and biting. In either context, my concern is what works.Critical realism. It is true that there is a duality, it is also true that the apple comes to us in different contexts, and it is further true that many of those contexts are social — shared ideas about what an apple is supposed to look and smell like, which determine my perception of this one.If I’m right about what you meant, then I believe I have answered you well.
